SENT.plain: The clinical picture of deep cerebral vein thromboses (DCVT) usually is acute, combining vigilance disorders, headaches, and focal neurologic deficit
The authors describe a patient who presented with isolated subacute dementia as the sole manifestation of DCVT
In the setting of subacute cognitive deficit, the diagnosis of DCVT must be considered when neuroimaging shows bilateral thalamic changes
Enhanced venous MR angiography is the noninvasive method of choice to ascertain the diagnosis
